citation.article-title: Butyrivibrio hungatei sp. nov. and Pseudobutyrivibrio xylanivorans sp. nov., butyrate-producing bacteria from the rumen.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pseudobutyrivibrio xylanivorans sp. nov.
Pseudobutyrivibrio xylanivorans (xy.la.ni.vo′rans. N.L. n. xylanum xylan; L. part. adj. vorans devouring, digesting; N.L. part. adj. xylanivorans xylan-digesting).
Cells are Gram-negative, straight to slightly curved rods (0·4–0·6×1·5–3·0 μm) that do not form endospores.
Cells are motile by means of a single polar or subpolar flagellum (Fig. 3).
Growth occurs anaerobically at 39 °C, but not at 25 or 45 °C.
No growth is observed in the presence of oxygen.
However, exposure of grown liquid culture to air for several hours does not destroy the ability of the species to recover under anaerobic conditions.
Substrates that support growth of the type strain are cellobiose, aesculin, glucose, lactose, maltose, mannose, melezitose, salicin, sucrose and xylose.
Tryptophan, urea and gelatin are not utilized.
The following substrates do not support growth of the type strain: glycerol; mannitol; raffinose; sorbitol; rhamnose; trehalose.
Medium M10 with glucose (22 mM) is fermented to formate (15·1 mM), butyrate (17·6 mM), lactate (10·9 mM), succinate (0·3 mM) and ethanol (1·1 mM).
Acetate is utilized.
No growth occurs in the absence of fermentable carbohydrates.
Strain Mz 5T does not liquefy gelatin or produce hydrogen sulfide; neither does it reduce nitrate, hydrolyse urea nor produce catalase.
It produces α-galactosidase, α-arabinosidase, xylanase, amylase, β-endoglucanase, pectin hydrolase, proteinase and DNase.

The major cellular fatty acid components of strain Mz 5T grown in DSM medium no. 330 without rumen fluid are C16 : 0 (39·2 %) and anteiso-C17 : 1 (6·4 %), followed by iso-C17 : 0 3-OH (3·9 %) and C14 : 0 (4·3 %).
This species is characterized by a higher content of straight-chain cellular fatty acids and a lower content of branched-chain fatty acids.
Produces high xylanase activity.
Most strains also produce amylase, proteinase and DNase.
Laminarinase is detected in some species.
Strains belonging to Pseudobutyrivibrio xylanivorans are listed in the footnote of Table 3.
The most common butyrate-producing anaerobic bacterium in our set of bacteria isolated from the rumen of sheep and cow.
The type strain is Mz 5T (=DSM 14809T =ATCC BAA-455T).
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 42·1 mol% (as determined by the HPLC method).
